items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 2:45pm and 4:45pm today Thursday 15th September. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.70mAODN at 3:45pm, Thursday 15th September, which is 0.24m above tide tables, wind Force 4, northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 5:30pm today Thursday 15th September.

floodArea.county: County Durham, Hartlepool, North Tyneside, South Tyneside, Sunderland

items.message:
Large and powerful waves are expected to affect the foreshore as a result of high spring tides and strong winds. Tides will be at their highest between 07:00 and 11:00 tomorrow morning, 16/09/22, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.
We expect flooding to affect beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads. The area most likely to be affected is Seaham Harbour and docks. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
We are closely monitoring the situation. This Alert may stay in force for the evening high tide, 16/09/22.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated at 12:00 tomorrow afternoon, 16/09/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is possible from 12pm this afternoon, Thursday 15th September and over the next 24hrs. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay. The current series of high spring tides has now reached its peak, and will fall away over the next few days, allowing the freshwater river flows to drain out to sea at low tide as normal again. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 8:30am tomorrow, Friday 16th September.

items.description: North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including tidal River Esk
items.message:
The flood alert for the North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including the tidal River Esk has been issued for tomorrow's tides. The area of particular concern is Sandsend, with wind driven wave overtopping expected from 10:00 until 11:15 GMT on the morning tide, and from 22:00 until 23:15 GMT on the evening tide, on Friday 16 September.

Strong northerly winds are likely to produce overtopping waves and spray along the coast, especially around Sandsend. Please be careful along beaches, coastal and estuary footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. We will continue to monitor the forecast closely. This message will be updated by 09:30 on Friday morning, 16 September, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message: Water levels in the Eastern Yar are now falling. The weather is expected to be dry through to the weekend giving river levels time to recover.
